newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares recoup some losses after HK fall.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares recoup some losses after HK fall.

text.p: Singapore shares ended lower on Friday after a turbulent day which saw the key index fall 60 points at one stage after a heavy fall in Hong Kong.
The benchmark 30-share Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) closed at 2,190.39, down 23.78 points on a active volume of 206.33 million shares.
A total of 382 shares lost ground and only 48 rose.

"Everything now depends on what happens on Wall Street and in London," said one dealer. "If they follow through, we could see lower numbers on Monday. But any way you look at it, I believe this will be a correction and an opportunity to buy."
Unlike Hong Kong, New York and London, Singapore has fallen this year and consistently underperformed rival stock markets.
Dealers had expected Singapore to fall in a correction to recent gains, but the scale of Friday's rout was a surprise.
It was sparked by overnight Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan who spoke of "irrational exuberance" in stock markets and raised some worries over future inflation and rate trends.
Almost all Singapore's large capitalisation STII stocks fell, led by drinks firm Fraser & Neave, which lost 40 cents to close at Singapore $15.10.

One of the few stable blue chips was Singapore Airlines foreign, which was flat at S$13.10 after Morgan Stanley recommended it as a core holding. The group gave SIA foreign a 12-month target of S$15.50.
